1094070611591266306.text:
Left: Sprout circuit, contains 2 inputs & 2 outputs.

Right: Two Sapling spend circuits and two Sapling output circuits, plus an "ignoreme" box to scale the "combined" circuit to be the same size as Sprout.

Two years of R&D at @zcashco  90% reduction in circuit size pic.twitter.com/SUU4JJtpPp

1094064732338819072.text: That is to say, if someone can come up with an algebraic PRF that we can be confident isn't broken, we can reduce the size of the spend circuit significantly https://github.com/zcash/zcash/issues/2233 …

1094063650724372480.text: There are two BLAKE2s calls in the Sapling spend circuit, which take up as much space as the entire Merkle path. We need them because there are two points in the cryptographic construction where we require a PRF (in the Merkle tree we can get away with just collision-resistance).

1094061601282576385.text:
Left: 25.2k constraints for a single SHA-256 block with no padding.

Right: 20.5k constraints for BLAKE2s. All of it!pic.twitter.com/KjiTxh6hEE

1094059655511375872.text:
Left: a single Sprout input. Right: the Sapling spend circuit.

Sprout has 29 SHA-256 hashes in a note's Merkle path, taking up 86% of the input's circuit! Sapling uses 32 Pedersen hashes, which at 1.3k constraints each are only 43% of its circuit.pic.twitter.com/nvbqgpZ7Yi

1094059654420852742.text: It's interesting looking at these visually, because the size of a zk-SNARK circuit affects the time it takes to create a proof. You can literally see the engineering improvements!

1094056661243830272.text: And to complete the set, here's the Sprout circuit we now use since Sapling activation. Same high-level circuit as before, but implemented using the proving system implementation and parameters that Sapling uses.pic.twitter.com/ApHR4w7vQE

1094048419553992704.text: For comparison, here is @socrates1024's rendering of the Sprout circuit. Sprout contains roughly the same logic as 2 Sapling spends and 2 Sapling outputs, so look at just the left-hand side when comparing them.https://twitter.com/socrates1024/status/948984484644483074 …

1094046618041679872.text: And the Sapling output circuit! You can see one of the reasons why we split it away from the spend side - it's much smaller and cheaper on its own.pic.twitter.com/eEP9I7BLoz

1094046240269053953.text:
Inspired by @socrates1024 rendering the Zcash Sprout circuit last year, I tried rendering the Sapling spend and output circuits today.

Here's the Sapling spend circuit!pic.twitter.com/gwq35HFpGL

906934022827364358.text: And that's it! #BreakingBitcoin is over! Thanks to the @breakingbitcoin team and speakers for all your work pic.twitter.com/8cdrBGV37k

906930571120607233.text: An impassioned call to develop current and new forms of technology for the benefit of individual and societal freedom.

906920244026990598.text: Last presentation for #BreakingBitcoin is @AmirPolyteknik with "Technology is a Power We Use to Shape Society"

906919770875973632.text: [Apologies to LO for missing things: the compression function in my brain wasn't operating correctly at your bitrate.]

906919127956295680.text: CD: LN works with any cryptocurrency, so could have a pegged coin. Once multicoin support in, could do atomic swaps.

906918993050718208.text: Q: Fiat Lightning for speculation? LO: There's someone working on a price oracle that could be used for this.

906918567811141633.text: CD: RPCs won't change at this point. ES: Various front-ends are available for testing with.

906918166122639361.text: Q: How can we check impl compatibility? CD: https://cdecker.github.io/lightning-integration/ …

906916961715675138.text: Q: Research resources, ideas? ES: http://dev.lightning.community/  CD: Best ideas come from students themselves. Also doing a PhD on Bitcoin is cool!

906916519552135169.text: LO: Also cool things like paying for storage.

906916100859990016.text: CD: Monetizing content for content producers, because I'm sick of ads. Fast, small, E2E payments. Just pay the person who wrote the article.

906915839932338177.text: Q: Applications? LO: Instant transfers between exchanges. Less custodial. ES: App dev! One demo doing LN for energy micropayments.

906914394508013568.text: LO: Can [in future?] have uni-directional vs bi-directional channels. [Not sure what that does for LN.]

906913943934967813.text: FD: Can simplify the watchtower use-case for mobile wallets [didn't catch how].

906913721771053057.text: ... But to shorten timeouts, can hand encrypted txn punishing peer to "watchtowers" for release in intervening time if peer misbehaves.

906913477696131072.text: Q: If I go offline, peer can reverse state and steal funds. Soln? CD: Tweakable peer timeout should be set longer than you are offline for.

906913041173925888.text: ES: Also looking at multi-sig. There will be a evolution of ways LNs are operated.

906912902485041152.text: CD: LN should only hold what you need for day-to-day activities. Don't put life savings in a LN channel. Temp limit in place for user safety

906912472317263872.text: Q: To route, you have to be online -> hot wallet. Theft mitigation? LO: Could separate keys for HTLC (online) and payments (offline).

906912005025648640.text: Q: Hardware? LO: [ERR_BUFFER_OVERFLOW] ES: Goal is to work on any hardware. LO: Trusted HW needs replay protection. [ERR_BUFFER_OVERFLOW]

906911356020031488.text: CD: Hard to hide values without higher fees [rounding?] LO: And even with CT can leak range. CD: Sphinx helps b/c don't know source or dest.

906910979249901569.text: Q: Is discrete-log solution to privacy issue worth it? LO: If we can improve privacy of system, will move towards that. Values not private.

906910580652552193.text: LO: [Something about how with MAST, LN can be more efficient] CD: Also can make txns look like any other txn - get indistinguishability.

906910157577256961.text: FD: Bitcoin needs global consensus; in LN interaction between two peers doesn't [need to?] affect rest of network.

906909889942999041.text: Q: How's compatibility going? ES: Really good interaction between the various impls! CD: Get some issues w/ new code, but finding & fixing.

906909185488691202.text: Now for the Lightning Network Panel! Featuring @starkness, Laolu Osuntokun, Fabrice Drouin and @Snyke.

906908724379385856.text: Q: Trade-offs here. What about other techniques? A: There will always be demand for on-chain transactions. Need soln that works on-chain.

906907850101977096.text: Q: Is mixing unidirectional? A: Yes, once coins get into post-mix wallet they stay there, subject to post-wallet rules.

906906943654166528.text: Plan is to have only one post-mix wallet impl, because important to have uniform implementation [and necessary for anonymity]

906906160141348867.text: Pre-mix wallet is linked to post-mix wallet via latter's extended public key. Need to keep it + derivatives secret from everyone.

906905013754220544.text: Defaults to Chaumian CoinJoin: use blinded addrs during tumbler signing, then unblind and send back anonymously to tumbler (e.g. via Tor).

906904157210193921.text: Pre-mix functionality is added to Bitcoin wallet. Coins transition from pre- to post- via mixing. [Can they transit backwards?]

906903785934651394.text: Post-mix wallet has strong privacy requirements [AFAICT requiring indistinguishability of e.g. transaction amounts].

906903107870830592.text: ZeroLink defines a pre-mix wallet state and a post-mix wallet state, with some mixing technique in between. Works with any mixing technique.

906901322036891650.text: Last #BreakingBitcoin session! Starting with @nopara73 and "Roadmap To Anonymous Bitcoin".

906893830632427520.text: Q: Efficiency in 10 years? JH: Mining follows semiconductor industry. Already heavily parallelized. Previous leaps were playing catch-up.

906893207098847234.text: AP: Bitcoin is currently searching for how to find consensus more efficiently. We are learning how to make decisions; no easy answer.

906892982217043968.text: KP: BIP9 was a mistake. To change protocol, hire devs to work on it, rather than blocking incoming changes.

906892837891047424.text: Q How much decision-power *should* miners have? JH: Ideal for miners' incentives to be aligned with users.

906892454913331200.text: Q: SHA256 broken? JH: We'd be okay, we mine things other than SHA256.

906892360247803904.text: ... and you decrease the value. But I like Bitcoin. If it *needs* to happen, go ahead. JH: Should only be if urgent.

906892059168198656.text: Q: PoW change? AP: If you change something in the basement, affects everything above. 1/25th of market cap invested in mining. Break that...

906891786630594561.text: [Last Q was not "are" as in precisely now.]

906891539313561601.text: JH: Two chains will happen, and light clients can't handle that. Q: What are you mining? JH: Currently Bitcoin. KP: Core, I think.

906874738781368320.text: Antifragile System: Evolving Dynamical System that improves as a result of stressors. AKA "What doesn't kill you makes you stronger".

906874246063849472.text: Corollary: Resilience improves with time. AKA "If it ain't broke, don't fix it!"

906874001527635968.text: Lindy Effect: Future life expectancy is proportional to its current age. AKA the "test of time". For BTC, life expectancy 4x that of ETH.

906837404195192833.text: 2) Max inputs for a block redeeming anyone-can-spend P2SH is around 24,000. 3) Attack block redeems *one* output from each of 24,000 txns.

906554033808306182.text: ... I have no problem w/ apps being built on top of HW wallets using TEEs, but I have a problem w/ [something about proof-of-elapsed-time].

906553747068907520.text: Q: Will we see coins based solely in TEEs, traded P2P without PoW? NB: Products could have a use-case (sending privkey via email?)...

906553458010050560.text: Q: if I am an enterprise, how do your products fit? S: We know many enterprises use TREZOR (w/ other HWWs in multisig), but not primary aim.

906553110163808257.text: Comment: TREZOR is focusing on a very different market - wallet-focused. S: Primary target is retail, end-users, not enterprise.

906552692511838208.text: S: In enterprise setup makes sense to check CPU itself. In home settings, many lower barriers to worry about than CPU being swapped.

906552142709657600.text: Follow-up Q: I can't verify what your SGX is running without having my own SGX validate? TB: We have separate attestation layers[? missed]

906551802899951616.text: Q: Diff. between being sure of what I'm running vs. what someone else is running. TB: Definitely work on stronger guarantees, but complex.

906551509789356032.text: S: No plan to use any virtualization or secure enclaves - aim to be as open as possible. Plans for physical separation of cores.

906551323876892672.text: TB: We're leveraging Nano, SGX, other TEEs (AWS?) and techniques (combining Google SafetyNet).

906551135863033858.text: NB: I think solutions like Teechain should be avoided, to keep the blockchains themselves trustless.

906550973472149504.text: Q: What kind of frameworks for TEEs? NB: Can already use Ledger Nano as TEE. Very similar to SGX. Main diff is you can decide to use or not.

906550595590467584.text: TB: Some approaches move complexity into TEE. Kinda cheating. But would be nice to split trust over different devices: cheat in a safer way.

906550451935555584.text: ... can be clear when they are making a LN payment vs. signing a tx. S: Same boat.

906550206858231808.text: Q: What about more complex tx formats? NB: Already have abstractions for dealing with different coins. Prob. use plugin system so users...

906549959104909313.text: TB: Nice to have e.g. Moxie so upper layers can target that and not worry about lower layers. Q: Maybe Rust bindings for Moxie?

906549831241551872.text: S: Evaluating many ways to limit attack vectors so HW layer isn't dealing w/ private keys.

906549478647312384.text: Q: How far along towards Rust? NB: Not very far. Probably easier for Trezor; we are limited to e.g. 50kB RAM, usually more like 10kB.

906549258635051009.text: Q: What kind of languages is the firmware written in? All: Lowest layers written in C. S (and NB?): Investigating Rust.

906548842660810752.text: ... or add support for other coins. NB: We're providing a simulation env so devs can run our firmware on general-purpose hardware to test.

906548545846738946.text: S: Trying to introduce more high-level concepts in business logic inside HW wallet itself, to make it easier for 3rd-party devs to review...

906548379471278080.text: Q: It's easy to download Bitcoin Core and look at the source. How are you making it easy to review, and try break, HW wallets?

906548208175910912.text: S: Easier because we are focused on a single use-case. Still need unit tests etc. and keeping everything as open as possible for review.

906547998313926656.text: Q: You could say the HW is almost software itself. How is quality ensured? NB: Same kinds of controls as for software, review, VCSs.

906547546314637312.text: S: Everything is better than storing keys on phones or desktop. Secure Enclave < HWW < multisig HW.

906547085096484864.text: [Missed a bunch of conversation here, technical glitch]

906546979832045568.text: Q: What do your products actually defend against? S: Combine usability and security. TB: Trying to find other workarounds to HW compromise.

906546824206589952.text: Last #BreakingBitcoin item of the day is the Hardware Panel, with @petertoddbtc (mod), @slushcz, Nicolas Bacca and @ThomasBertani.

906545372700573701.text: Q: This would also work on same core, right? A: Yes, but attack is more powerful because it doesn't care which core it runs on.

906544990695907328.text: Q: Could you combine with e.g. RowHammer to replace a victim key with an attacker one? A: No, memory is encrypted and integrity-checked.

906544490781052928.text: Or, just spend more money and provide a non-shared secure memory element.

906544231573008386.text: Intel could also prevent by using Cache Allocation Technology with SGX (instead of controlling CAT from OS, combine with SGX eenter).

906544019127316483.text:
Other ideas:
- Enclave coloring to prevent cross-enclave attacks.
- Heap randomization to randomize cache sets (makes attack harder).

906543788457426944.text: Need to resist cache attacks at the software level. Also would be nice to be able to inspect enclave code from OS (even with trust issues).

906543370948026368.text: Ooh look, it's a private key being leaked out of an SGX enclave!pic.twitter.com/qHsu2BNu4V

906543066143748096.text: Result after implementation: it works, can detect borders of memory banks (red dots).pic.twitter.com/1raym7f9CH

906542589570142209.text: Hmm, no knowledge of physical addresses. But, we can use reverse-engineered DRAM layout plus timing to figure addresses of banks out!

906542222287523840.text: But Intel disabled the timing needed for the attack for security reasons. What about incrementing a global in a thread? Oh, it's 15% faster!

906541898982199297.text: PLOT TWIST: Put the attacker inside SGX too! Now in same core, and the attacker is completely hidden from OS by SGX itself. Untraceable!pic.twitter.com/8wqHljTkhF

906541367354163202.text: So, what happens if you use a vulnerable signature algorithm? Well, if victim's wallet is inside SGX, it's secure, right?

906541144871456769.text: Motivation here is that the attacker and victim run on the same CPU in different cores, but using the shared CPU cache.

906540849198223360.text: Summary of Prime+Probe Cache Attack: exploits timing difference when accessing cached vs uncached data. Attacks secret-dependent mem access.

906540543777415169.text: But, SGX explicitly defines side-channel attacks as out-of-scope. Huh.

906540104415694849.text: Summary of SGX: do trusted parts inside via calls to the Trusted Execution Environment. OS is outside the trust boundary.pic.twitter.com/nokhQtlh1t

906539548502618112.text: Next up: @lavados and Michael Schwarz talking about "Cash Attacks on SGX".

906537895099600896.text: And it comes with a game, to encourage attempts at breaking! https://github.com/LedgerHQ/bolos-enclave-catchme …

906537499908100096.text: So, Ledger are trying to build a virtualized hardware wallet: https://github.com/ledgerhq/bolos-enclave …

906537103571513345.text: *But* can optionally get trusted display, I/O. Could use attestation (correctly) to ensure integrity of blockchain, then go trustless.

906536474497208321.text: But doesn't help much to defend against access to the computer. Still has all the existing problems, and probably new ones.

906536333279199232.text: Could we have "HW wallets" on existing hardware? Attractive; achieved w/ modern CPUs with isolation mode (Intel SGX, ARM TrustZone(?)).

906535964918603776.text: Note on confusing forks: BCH used same addr format, and the replay protection works for sending but too late for receiving. Complicates HWW.

906535531194077186.text: Evil wallet like above is hard to detect; the MCU can be as transparent as it needs to be.

906535281721008128.text: [That's the layout the previous tweets were following, hard to keep switching devices here at speed!]pic.twitter.com/e6ggVNo1Ce

906534935246274561.text: Newer idea is a Secure MCU. No proof of origin, but auditable (up to proprietary mechanisms).

906534772725440513.text: Some use generic MCU as proxy, with separate Secure Element containing business logic. Proof-of-origin, but limited auditability?

906534482940919808.text: Now covering different architectures used inside various HW wallets. Most common (@TREZOR etc.) use dedicated chips. Generic MCU less common

906533924402352128.text: There's a security-vs-convenience trade-off for users: sometimes it isn't possible to retain user information during a security upgrade.

906533752968540163.text: Most HW wallets aim to defend against not-too-intrusive attacks. Read-only bootloader to verify/reflash firmware, which in turn handles apps

906533382858866688.text: Lab attacks are very hard to defend against. If someone can decap your chip containing the secret keys, there's not a lot you can do.

906533220677820416.text: ... and fault injection - actively messing with the voltages etc. to induce bugs or changes in the operational code.

906533089249284096.text: Shack attacks have two categories: observational leaks (timing / power analysis), which are non-invasive and non-detectable, impl-dependent.

906532727016607744.text: Hack attacks involve all the usual suspects - need good engineering process, testing, review etc. to defend against.

906532380772532224.text:
How to break hardware?

- Hack attack: software
- "Shack attack": low-budget hardware
- Lab attack: Eran Tromer, behind a wall, with a radio

906531824192671745.text: Design goals: protect against malware (protect keys), physical theft, bad crypto(graphy) (good RNG, resist side-channels).

906531602678927360.text: Why hardware wallets? Because you should assume your regular computer is compromised, or at least public.

906531197622345728.text: Okay, last #BreakingBitcoin session of the day! Kicking off with @BTChip on "Breaking Hardware Wallets".

906524020916588544.text: LN: Also self-selecting reports. We only hear from users that come to us.

906523778880024576.text: Q: You talked about occurrence of losing keys vs stolen funds. But what about value of funds? TV: We don't have enough theft to get stats.

906523491733835777.text: [Disclaimer: I doubt I am doing justice to this particular discussion - I'm not familiar with either BIP.]

906523348401885185.text: ... But newcomers won't bother implementing it. Co-author: Version bits aren't enforceable across impls. TV: Then why is there a BIP?

906523149713408000.text: ... At some point it will be safe to drop BIP44. TV: It won't ever be safe for you or I to drop BIP44 if we've ever issued seeds with it.

906523025532649477.text: TV: I think it's better for security to have a version number in the format. Co-author: There are hundreds of thousands of wallets...

906522466503348225.text: ... It's not practical to assume that a backup seed can work seamlessly across all wallets. Safer to assume it will work in the same kind.

906522213804855297.text: Q: Hi, I'm co-author of BIP39 *chuckle, applause*

906521693593722880.text: Q from @giacomozucco: Do you prefer your coins to be stolen or lost? TV: I'll turn that question right back on you.

906521243918245888.text: Q: What are you excited about? A from all: Lightning Network. MP: And general interoperability, bringing partners together.

906520683580198912.text: MP: We can never get to a memorable mnemonic, unless it's weak enough to be useless. Users *need* to write them down.

906520467909091328.text: LN: Wallet format def. needs start date to avoid scanning from beginning of "time". Also issues with master -> xpriv because one-way func?

906520071132106754.text: Q: Should they write down the date they created wallet? TV: And software version, and probably more.

906520003431858176.text: TV: Wallets won't implement every standard, user might only see a fraction of the coins that are really theirs.

906519870992461825.text: LN: You can use 39 without 43. TV: Not good enough. I believe there should be absolute certainty of recovery.

906519553949290496.text: Q: BIP39+43? TV: Against: there's no guarantee you can recover spending keys from backup phrase; derivation paths not specified.

906519183030185984.text: MP: There's a proliferation of PoCs in short term, but rushing out to prod without security review, thought about immutability is a threat.

906518725309992961.text: LN: Chain audit is only half, still have fiat side. I think exchanges could do much better (e.g. payment channels for securing  funds).

906518691294183424.text: Q: Do you have concerns with exchanges operating on fractional basis? TV: Could add something to Electrum to enable checking of chain.

906518210354323457.text: TV: But do see e.g. initial use of wallets not actually in their control. LN: Malware a problem (e.g. swap address in UI just before send).

906517985262784512.text: Q: How do users usually lose funds? TV: More often lose funds by forgetting private key, or not writing down backup phrases, than theft.

906517661311479813.text: LN: Some great identity ideas (e.g. proving I'm from Europe without revealing which country), but need to ensure privacy of the database.

906517470743232514.text: TV: What about money? LN: I don't want mixing of money & identity, for fungibility - my wallet should never know who I am. MP: Diff wallets.

906517151846150145.text: Q: Where do you see demand beyond banking, identity? MP: Governance (e.g. Estonia), healthcare (prescriptions).

906516818487017472.text: MP: All layers need to be secure, not just the blockchain (thinking of e.g. Lightning network).
